title: Massive Lower GI Bleed from Angiodysplasia
setup_script: A 70-year-old man presents with maroon stools and syncope. He is on anticoagulation for atrial fibrillation. His blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg and heart rate 110 bpm. Initial resuscitation stabilizes him.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Initiate resuscitation: place two large bore IV lines, order type and cross, administer fluids and transfuse blood products as needed.
Hold anticoagulation and reverse if necessary with vitamin K or prothrombin complex concentrate.
Perform focused history on previous GI bleeding, comorbidities, and medications; conduct rectal exam.
Order labs including CBC, coagulation profile, liver function tests; insert NG tube to rule out upper GI bleed if uncertain.
Arrange urgent colonoscopy after rapid bowel preparation with nasogastric lavage or enemas to localize bleeding source.
During colonoscopy, identify angiodysplasia in cecum; treat with endoscopic thermal coagulation (argon plasma coagulation).
If colonoscopy fails to localize or control bleeding, consider CT angiography or tagged RBC scan to identify active bleeding.
For ongoing bleeding, consult interventional radiology for superselective mesenteric angiography and embolization.
If nonoperative management fails or patient becomes unstable, proceed with segmental colectomy of bleeding source.
Discuss surgical risks and obtain informed consent emphasizing high morbidity in emergency colectomy.
Post-treatment care: monitor hemoglobin, hemodynamics, and stool output; restart anticoagulation when safe.
Educate patient on risk factors for angiodysplasia, potential recurrence, and need for follow-up colonoscopy.

critical_decision_points: Aggressive resuscitation and anticoagulation reversal in acute bleeding.
Timely colonoscopy and endoscopic treatment of angiodysplasia.
Use of angiography or surgery when endoscopic therapy fails.
Decision on when to operate based on hemodynamic stability and localization.
